final_answer.precision_note: Mass uses purity-adjusted CaCO3 moles and given molar masses, reported to 3 significant figures.

method: Find the mass of pure calcium carbonate: m(CaCO3) = 5.00 g × 84.0% = 4.20 g. Use moles = m / M_r with M_r(CaCO3) = 100.1 g mol^-1 to give n(CaCO3) = 4.20 / 100.1 = 0.0419 mol. From stoichiometry, CaCO3 + 2HCl → CO2 + ... gives 1 mol CO2 per 1 mol CaCO3, so n(CO2) = 0.0419 mol. Convert to mass with M_r(CO2) = 44.0 g mol^-1: m(CO2) = 0.0419 × 44.0 = 1.85 g. Acid is in excess, so this is the maximum CO2 mass.
checks: Purity is applied by mass, reducing 5.00 g to 4.20 g before stoichiometry.
Stoichiometry ratio is one-to-one between CaCO3 and CO2 in the provided equation.
Calculated CO2 mass 1.85 g uses all available pure CaCO3 moles, giving a maximum possible product mass.
